Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an In situ Infrared Spectroscopy System for Research and Teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation program (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities program (CRIF), West Virginia University will acquire an infrared spectroscopy system equipped with a high pressure reactor. A basic infrared spectrometer system provides spectroscopic data in the infrared region of the spectrum. These data give information about the vibrational frequencies of a substance, thus providing insight on the chemical composition and structure of the materials under investigation. Infrared spectroscopy is a widely used tool in understanding the properties of chemical and biological systems and in materials research. The in situ high pressure reactor will allow the study of reactions and products subjected to pressures above ambient conditions. This tool will advance the training of students in their research and course work at all levels. The instrumentation will be made available to researchers at other institutions in the region.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as studying (a) heterogeneous oxidation of biomass materials and catalytic conversion of combustion pollutants, (b) catalytic C-C bond forming reactions including reductive coupling of carbon monoxide and dehydrogenative cross-coupling, (c) organometallic reactions catalyzed by late transition metals ligated to an ambiphilic, multifunctional, and 1,2,3-triazole ligand systems, and (d) palladium-catalyzed pathways for making nitrogen heterocycles of biological importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A React IR 15 in situ infrared spectroscopy system was purchased from Mettler-Toledo and installed at West Virginia University in December 2013. Infrared spectroscopy is a well-developed technique to characterize organic and inorganic compounds and materials; however, its use for monitoring of chemical reactions in real-time necessitates more specialized instrumentation. The state-of-the-art instrumentation acquired with NSF funds allows researchers at WVU to probe the mechanisms of chemical reactions that otherwise would be challenging to probe with more traditional experimental techniques. The knowledge acquired through such mechanistic studies is critically important when working at the frontiers of chemistry. This instrument is the first of its kind to be installed at WVU. It has had a significant impact on several on-going research programs and enables the students at WVU to be introduced to modern technology.

Several research programs at WVU have been significantly impacted by the ReactIR 15 instrumentation. New synthetic methodologies for accessing functionalized [n]cycloparaphenylenes (CPPs), so called nanohoops, have been developed and studied. These new molecules may serve as templates for future synthetic pathways to prepare carbon nanotubes of uniform diameter and molecular composition. New catalytic carboxylation and decarboxylation strategies using environmentally friendly and inexpensive earth-abundant catalysts have been developed and the mechanisms elucidated. These studies open new avenues for the utilization of carbon dioxide, an important but underutilized carbon feedstock, in chemical transformations. In addition, fundamental experimental and computational studies of reactions of highly reactive combustion intermediates have been undertaken. The work contributes important data necessary for developing accurate combustion models that will be key to the discovery of new combustion strategies for lower carbon emissions.  

Postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students received hands-on research experience with this state-of-the-art instrumentation. It is important that chemists are trained with modern instrumentation commonly used in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Graduate and undergraduate students were also provided technical training in advanced undergraduate laboratory classes and graduate coursework. The Bennett Department of Chemistry at WVU predominantly serves many students from Appalachia, an economically depressed region, who are often first-generation students and are underrepresented in higher education. The opportunities for career development made possible with this instrumentation supports the mission of the Department to develop students that will choose a STEM field for their career and make meaningful contributions to society through their future work.
